user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is: Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of close_connection:
```c
static void
close_connection (struct MHD_Connection *pos)
{
  struct MHD_Daemon *daemon = pos->daemon;

#ifdef MHD_USE_THREADS
  mhd_assert ( (! MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_ (daemon)) || \
               MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_current_thread_ (daemon->tid) );
  mhd_assert (NULL == daemon->worker_pool);
#endif /* MHD_USE_THREADS */

  if (MHD_D_IS_USING_THREAD_PER_CONN_ (daemon))
  {
    MHD_connection_mark_closed_ (pos);
    return;   /* must let thread to do the rest */
  }
  MHD_connection_close_ (pos,
                         MHD_REQUEST_TERMINATED_DAEMON_SHUTDOWN);
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_lock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
#endif
  mhd_assert (! pos->suspended);
  mhd_assert (! pos->resuming);
  if (pos->connection_timeout_ms == daemon->connection_timeout_ms)
    XDLL_remove (daemon->normal_timeout_head,
                 daemon->normal_timeout_tail,
                 pos);
  else
    XDLL_remove (daemon->manual_timeout_head,
                 daemon->manual_timeout_tail,
                 pos);
  DLL_remove (daemon->connections_head,
              daemon->connections_tail,
              pos);
  DLL_insert (daemon->cleanup_head,
              daemon->cleanup_tail,
              pos);
  daemon->data_already_pending = true;
#if defined(MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS) || defined(MHD_USE_W32_THREADS)
  MHD_mutex_unlock_chk_ (&daemon->cleanup_connection_mutex);
#endif
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of any <string.h> functions (memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, strspn, etc.) in the provided close_connection function. The function contains assertions, mutex lock/unlock calls, calls to MHD_connection_close_, and list-manipulation macros/functions (XDLL_remove, DLL_remove, DLL_insert). None of those calls in this fragment directly invoke the standard string-handling APIs targeted by MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. Therefore there are no code fragments in this function that need investigation for out-of-bounds accesses caused by <string.h> functions.

Note: If any of the called functions or macros (MHD_connection_close_, XDLL_remove, DLL_remove, DLL_insert, or any macros expanded here) are defined elsewhere and internally use <string.h> functions in a way that could access memory out-of-bounds, those definitions should be inspected. However, those implementations are not present in the supplied code fragment and so are outside the scope of this review of this function body.
